Problem:
Consider a system described by the function \( z = f(x, y) \) where \( f(x, y) = x^2 + iy^2 \), and \( x, y \) are real variables. Here, we further explore the effect of the integral transformation defined by \( T[f](\omega) = \int_{-\infty}^\infty f(x, y) e^{-i\omega x} dx \) on this system.

If \( T[f](\omega) \) is computed initially for some \(\omega\), then no further transformations are applied, and only the underlying function \( f \) evolves by adjusting \( x \) and \( y \), will \( T[f](\omega) \) at a later time reflect the changes in \( x \) and \( y \) linearly through \( \omega \)?
Explanation: The transformation \( T[f](\omega) \) captures the frequency component of \( f \) with respect to \( x \) and not \( y \). Any changes in \( y \) will lead to a change in the imaginary part of \( f \), especially since \( y^2 \) will contribute a biasing term, but will not linearly influence the outcome of \( T[f](\omega) \), which is primarily sensitive to changes in \( x \).
